revised_title: Circular Dichroism as a Measure of Superhelix Density: A Theoretical Study
tldr: This article investigates the use of circular dichroism as a measure of superhelix density in DNA. The authors explore the effect of supercoiling on DNA structure and function, and discuss the potential of circular dichroism as a non-destructive and accurate method for measuring superhelix density. They provide a theoretical explanation of the experimental spectra and consider the role of secondary, tertiary, and curvature effects on the optical activity of DNA.
